data.text: A prostrate southern Brazilian plant (Arachis hypogaea) widely cultivated in tropical and warm temperate regions, having yellow flowers on stalks that bend over so that the seed pods ripen underground.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: The edible, nutlike, oily seed of this plant, used for food and as a source of oil.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: A peanut-shaped piece of polystyrene, used in cushioning items during shipment.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.
from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: A small child. Often used as a term of affection.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: A person who is regarded as insignificant.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: A very small amount of money; a trifling sum.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: One of the edible fruits of Arachis hypogæn.
The plant that bears these fruits, better known in England as groundnut. See Arachis. Also called ground-pea, earthnut, Manila nut, jur-nut, goober, and pindar.
The fruit of a trailing leguminous plant (<spn>Arachis hypogæa</spn>); also, the plant itself, which is widely cultivated for its fruit.
data.attributionText: from the GNU version of the Collaborative International Dictionary of English.
